title: Interpretable Graph Neural Networks for Heterogeneous Tabular Data
abstract:
Many machine learning algorithms for tabular data produce black-box models,
which prevent users from understanding the rationale behind the model
predictions. In their unconstrained form, graph neural networks fall into this
category, and they have further limited abilities to handle heterogeneous data.
To overcome these limitations, an approach is proposed, called IGNH
(Interpretable Graph Neural Network for Heterogeneous tabular data), which
handles both categorical and numerical features, while constraining the
learning process to generate exact feature attributions together with the
predictions. A large-scale empirical investigation is presented, showing that
the feature attributions provided by IGNH align with Shapley values that are
computed post hoc. Furthermore, the results show that IGNH outperforms two
powerful machine learning algorithms for tabular data, Random Forests and
TabNet, while reaching a similar level of performance as XGBoost.
